name: diethyl ether production | water, decarbonised | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/6996/documentation

General comment: Diethyl ether is produced through three main production routes: 1) As a by-product during ethylene hydration (where ethanol is the reference product). This production route produces most of the production volume of diethyl ether (Ullmann’s Encyclopedia). 2) As a reference product in the sulphuric acid process (= ethanol dehydration). 3) As a reference product in catalytic dehydration over alumn. This activity represent production route no.2. 

The activity starts when the raw materials enters the process.

Materials entering the process are included as well as energy uses, infrastructure and emissions.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The production process presented in this activity is the sulphuric acid process of ethanol dehydration to diethyl ether (Brown, W.H. 2009, Organic Chemistry). The amount of chemicals on the input and output are calculated using stoichiometric relations. The yield of the reaction is 95%. Ethanol and sulfuric acid are heated to ca. 125°C in a ration of 1:3. The ether is distilled with part of the unreacted alcohol. Any sulfuric acid present in the destilate is removed by washing with dilute sodium hydroxide solution. Ethanol is introduced into the sulfuric acid either in vapor or in liquid form depending on the degree of conversion. The process runs continuously for several months and is then stopped to replace the sulfuric acid, which becomes heavily contaminated with tar-like polymers (Ullmann's Encyclopedia). The this polluted sulfuric acid is neutralized with sodium hydroxide before released to the environment.

exchanges.description: Stoichiometric calculation, yield of 95%.

exchanges.description: In case of ethanol, part of the unreacted volume evaporates as emission to air (0.2% of the input), the rest is released as a part of wastewater. The efficiency of the waste water treatment plant (WWTP) is assumed to be 90%, i.e. 10% of the volume of ethanol on the inflow to the WWTP is released to the environment (water).

exchanges.description: In case of sulfuric acid, part of the unreacted volume evaporates as emission to air (0.2% of the input), the rest is released in the form of sulfur (S) to the environment. During the reaction sulfuric acid is transformed into HSO4-. This is neutralized with sodium hydroxide and released into environment as sulfur.

flow.name: Sulfur
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to water/unspecified

exchanges.description: The unreacted ethanol is assumed to leave the production process with the wastewater. This amount is calculated taken into account losses of 0.2% raw material as air emissions, and the efficiency of the reaction (95%). Further it is assumed that this wastewater is treated in an internal wastewater plant. Therefore, a removal efficiency of 90% for ethanol is assumed. The carbon contained in the removed ethanol is accounted as CO2 emissions to air.
